               String key,
               String value,
               Charset encoding)
                        throws URISyntaxException
        This method adds a single key/value parameter to the query string of a given URI. Existing keys will be overwritten.
        Parameters:

        key - the key
        value - the value
        encoding - the encoding
        Returns:
        the URI

      • decode

        public static String decode(String s,
            Charset encoding)
        Decodes an octet according to RFC 2396. According to this spec, any characters outside the range 0x20 - 0x7E must be escaped because they are not printable characters, except for any characters in the fragment identifier. This method will translate any escaped characters back to the original.
        Parameters:
        s - the URI to decode
        encoding - the encoding to decode into
        Returns:
        The decoded URI

      • encode

        public static String encode(String s,
            Charset encoding)

        Escape a string into URI syntax

        This function applies the URI escaping rules defined in section 2 of [RFC 2396], as amended by [RFC 2732], to the string supplied as the first argument, which typically represents all or part of a URI, URI reference or IRI. The effect of the function is to replace any special character in the string by an escape sequence of the form %xx%yy..., where xxyy... is the hexadecimal representation of the octets used to represent the character in US-ASCII for characters in the ASCII repertoire, and a different character encoding for non-ASCII characters.

        If the second argument is true, all characters are escaped other than lower case letters a-z, upper case letters A-Z, digits 0-9, and the characters referred to in [RFC 2396] as "marks": specifically, "-" | "_" | "." | "!" | "~" | "" | "'" | "(" | ")". The "%" character itself is escaped only if it is not followed by two hexadecimal digits (that is, 0-9, a-f, and A-F).

        [RFC 2396] does not define whether escaped URIs should use lower case or upper case for hexadecimal digits. To ensure that escaped URIs can be compared using string comparison functions, this function must always use the upper-case letters A-F.

        The character encoding used as the basis for determining the octets depends on the setting of the second argument.

        Parameters:
        s - the String to convert
        encoding - The encoding to use for unsafe characters
        Returns:
        The converted String

      • encodeQueryString

        public static URI encodeQueryString(String s)
                             throws URISyntaxException
        This method takes a String of an URI with an unescaped query string and converts it into a URI with encoded query string format. Useful for processing command line input.
        Parameters:
        s - the URI string
        Returns:
        a string with the URL encoded data.
        Throws:
        URISyntaxException

      • parseQueryString

        public static Map<String,String> parseQueryString(URI uri)
        This method parses a query string and returns a map of decoded request parameters. We do not rely on java.net.URI because it does not decode plus characters. The encoding is UTF-8.
        Parameters:
        uri - the URI to examine for request parameters
        Returns:
        a map

      • parseQueryString

        public static Map<String,String> parseQueryString(URI uri,
                                  Charset encoding)
        This method parses a query string and returns a map of decoded request parameters. We do not rely on java.net.URI because it does not decode plus characters.
        Parameters:
        uri - the URI to examine for request parameters
        encoding - the encoding
        Returns:
        a Map

      • parseQueryString

        public static Map<String,String> parseQueryString(URI uri,
                                  Charset encoding,
                                  URIUtil.ParameterListener listener)
        This method parses a query string and returns a map of decoded request parameters. We do not rely on java.net.URI because it does not decode plus characters. A listener can process the parameters in order.
        Parameters:
        uri - the URI to examine for request parameters
        encoding - the encoding
        listener - a listner for processing the URI parameters in order, or null
        Returns:
        a Map of parameters

      • renderQueryString

        public static String renderQueryString(Map<String,String> m)
        This method takes a Map of key/value elements and converts it into a URL encoded querystring format.
        Parameters:
        m - a map of key/value arrays
        Returns:
        a string with the URL encoded data

        Returns:
        a string
